group_1.textRight: I heard you saw a Kōwakamai performance.@Did you like Atsumori?

group_1.textLeft: More than that. It truly touched my heart.
No matter the era, conflict is an eternal constant.@We are in flux, and the world is ever fragile…

group_1.textRight: Indeed.
Kumagai Naozane, having lost his son,@kills the sixteen-year-old Atsumori.
Such ruthlessness comes with war.
Perhaps that's why the story resonates@with the samurai.

group_1.textLeft: I may find myself in Naozane's position@someday.
Speaking of which, there was a quote from@Atsumori that I'm trying to understand…

group_1.narration: "Human life is merely fifty years long.@Compared to life in Geten, everything@is naught but dream and illusion."

group_1.textLeft: But I would not call fifty years "mere,"@would you?

group_1.textRight: Good question.
In the Buddhist divine realm,@Geten is the lowest layer of heaven.
One day there is equivalent to fifty years@in the real world.
What's more, its inhabitants live to be@five hundred years old.

group_1.textLeft: Hm…so if one day is 50 years, and they survive@to 500…do people there die after ten days?

group_1.textRight: No, don't divide the five hundred by fifty.
Fifty years in our world is one day in Geten.@After 364 of those days,
a single year will finally pass in Geten.
Correct. Fifty years times 364 equals one year@in Geten.
After factoring in the leap month, the five@hundred years spent in Geten…
…equals 9,120,000 years in our world.

group_1.textLeft: I'm sorry, but this has already put me out@of my depth...
Ah, but with your explanation,@I understand now.

group_1.narration: "Human life is merely fifty years long.@Compared to life in Geten, everything@is naught but dream and illusion."

group_1.textLeft: Fifty of our years passes by in the blink@of an eye for those in Geten.

group_1.textRight: So you see.
Princess, you must return to the manor soon,@or Lord Masatsuna will be worried.

group_1.textLeft: Goodness, it really has gotten late.
Well then, we shall pay our respects@to the sacred tree on our way home.

group_1.textRight: But it's almost pitch-black out!
Don't cause them too much trouble, Tsuyu.

group_1.textLeft: I really mustn't?@Very well, we'll go straight home.

group_1.textRight: That would be much appreciated,@Your Highness…!
Also, you really shouldn't visit the temple@so often.
It's not that women are forbidden@from entering,
but I fear that the other monks may see us,@and…make assumptions.
You don't sound serious.

group_1.textLeft: *Giggle* As I said, I'll be mindful.

group_1.textCenter: Now then, which story shall I have Gen'un@explain next…

group_1.textRight: What are they saying…?

group_1.narration: "Although it is near Suitoku Temple,@that hill has long been of utmost@importance to the Mizuna Clan…"
"They must be constructing the shrine@in order to completely destroy Mizuna's@authority, or there would be no talk@of felling the sacred tree…"
"Lord Sumiya is skilled in cunning.@His son may be easier to deal with,@but as long as the man draws breath,@we don't have much room to navigate."

group_1.textRight: …[wait:0.8][chara:104501:cheek_0][chara:104501:face_mtn_ex_020.exp3.txt][chara:104501:motion_200][chara:104501:lipSynch_1]Our sacred tree…
